title: Intimacy & Closeness
description: Explore what true intimacy means to you and how you achieve it.

questions.text: What does deep intimacy feel like to me?

therapeutic.rationale: Intimacy definitions reveal attachment needs. Known-and-accepted seekers need validation; comfortable-silence lovers value presence without performance; physical-closeness seekers bond through body; vulnerability-safety seekers need emotional security. What feels intimate to you is your intimacy blueprint.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different intimacy definitions may feel like missing each other. The silence-lover may feel the vulnerability-seeker needs too much processing; the physical-seeker may feel the known-accepted seeker is always analyzing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared intimacy definitions make deep connection easier. You feel intimate in the same ways and will naturally create what feels close to both.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does deep intimacy feel like to you? When have you felt it in this relationship? What would create more of it?

questions.text: What blocks me from feeling truly close to you?
choices: Fear of being too much or not enough

therapeutic.rationale: Intimacy blocks reveal attachment wounds. Too-much-or-not-enough fear creates performing; independence-loss fear creates distance-keeping; past-hurts create protective walls; trust-difficulty creates testing. Understanding what blocks intimacy is the first step to removing the barrier.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different intimacy blocks need different patience. The independence-loser needs space reassurance; the past-hurt person needs consistent safety. Know each other's blocks.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared intimacy blocks create understanding but may also create reinforcement. Two trust-difficult people may both hold back, creating less intimacy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What blocks you from feeling fully close? Where does this barrier come from? What would help you lower it?

questions.text: How do I show you that I want to be closer?
choices: I share more of my inner world

therapeutic.rationale: Closeness-seeking signals vary by attachment and love language. Conversation-initiators seek emotional connection; affection-increasers seek physical bonding; time-creators seek presence; inner-world sharers seek intimacy through disclosure. Recognizing your partner's closeness signals helps you receive their bids.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different closeness signals may be missed. The inner-world sharer may not see the affection-increaser's bid as closeness-seeking. Learn your partner's signals.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared closeness signals make recognition easy. You see each other's closeness bids because you make the same ones.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you signal wanting to be closer? Does your partner recognize these signals? Would clearer communication help?

questions.text: What helps me open up more deeply?
choices: Feeling that you truly want to understand me
Knowing my vulnerability won't be used against me
Your patience when I struggle to express myself

therapeutic.rationale: Opening-up conditions reveal vulnerability requirements. Understanding-wanting provides attunement safety; not-used-against provides trust safety; patience provides process safety; you-first provides reciprocity safety. Creating your partner's opening-up conditions enables deeper intimacy.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different opening conditions need different creation. The you-first person needs your vulnerability modeling; the patience-needer needs time without pressure. Provide your partner's conditions.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared opening conditions make intimacy easier. You know what enables vulnerability because you need the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What conditions help you open up? Does your partner provide these? How could you create them together?

questions.text: How has our relationship deepened my capacity for intimacy?
choices: I've become more comfortable being vulnerable
I've learned to receive love more easily
I've opened up about things I've never shared
I've become more secure in closeness

therapeutic.rationale: Intimacy growth reflects earned security. Vulnerability-comfort shows opening; receiving-love shows allowing in; never-shared-sharing shows deeper trust; closeness-security shows settling in. Relationships can heal attachment wounds and expand intimacy capacity.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different intimacy growth celebrates different progress. Honor whatever growth edge your partner is working on, even if different from yours.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared intimacy growth means you're developing together. Celebrate how far you've come and support continued expansion.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How has this relationship grown your capacity for intimacy? What helped most? What's your next growth edge?
